12.title: "Film and Comic Art : A Critique of the Purist View"
12.author: Armand Eisen
12.appears_in: p. 12-15 in The Harvard Journal of Pictorial Fiction (Spring 1974)
notes: SUMMARY: "Rudolph Arnheim declares in his landmark Film as Art, 'The indirectness of language ... makes words fade into meaningless noise when they are forced to compete on an equal footing with visual and auditory action.' This is representative of the purist stand that film with sound and comics with dialogue and prose are hybrid, uncontrolled forms of artistic expression. The author argues that the 'sound' dimension is vital to the functional object of emotional involvement and aesthetically sound as partner to visual storytelling."

15.heading: Film and Comics.
15.title: "Heartbreak Soup: The Interdependence of Theme and Form"
15.author: Charles Hatfield
notes: Summary: Discusses a volume of G. and J. Hernandez' Love and Rockets.

Annotation (by Gene Kannenberg): While Heartbreak Soup is its primary focus, the article makes excellent use of film terminology as a tool; Hatfield doesn't fall into the trap of transplanting the terminology whole-scale, but rather proposes and uses some aspects, explaining just how and why they are useful in a comics context.

121.heading: Film as Art--Miscellanea.
121.title: "Film and Comic Art : A Critique of the Purist View"
121.author: Armand Eisen
121.appears_in: p. 12-15 in The Harvard Journal of Pictorial Fiction (Spring 1974)
notes: SUMMARY: "Rudolph Arnheim declares in his landmark Film as Art, 'The indirectness of language ... makes words fade into meaningless noise when they are forced to compete on an equal footing with visual and auditory action.' This is representative of the purist stand that film with sound and comics with dialogue and prose are hybrid, uncontrolled forms of artistic expression. The author argues that the 'sound' dimension is vital to the functional object of emotional involvement and aesthetically sound as partner to visual storytelling."

133.heading: Un Film en Planches Dessinées.
133.title: "Le Roman Dessiné : un 'Film en Planches Dessinées'"
133.author: Sylviette Giet
133.appears_in: p. 44-51 in 9e Art : les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 6 (Jan. 2001).
notes: Begins: "Parmi les multiples bandes dessinées proposées au lectorat féminin, un partie d'entre elles relèvent d'un sous-genre spécifique, désigné par ses éditeurs comme 'roman dessiné'. Un sous-genre qui sera un des grands succès de la presse d'après-guerre, et fondera celui de la 'presse du cœur'. Mais ce roman sentimental en images tend à se présenter come substitut de film plus que comme bande dessinée."

English summary (from page 150): "A Film in Comic Strip Form. Before being replaced by the fumetti, the 'graphic novel' which presented itself as a substitute for a film, constituted an important part of romance publications in post war years. Sylvette Giet recounts the brief acme of this genre that originated in Italy and in which some great artists such as Walter Molino distinguished themselves."

186.heading: Filmmakers.
186.title: Narcissa
186.author: by Lance Tooks.
notes: Cover blurb: "Narcissa, a talented and self-centered independent filmmaker, is collapsing under the strain of her critics, the 'enlightened' people who are trying to get her to compromise her integrity. The stress is killing her, literally. Warned that if she tries to complete her current project she'll be dead in a week, Narcissa decides to escape the chaos that surrounds her, and the fears that threaten to overwhelm her, by traveling to Spain. As she encounters new people, places, and experiences, Narcissa gradually comes to a deeper understanding of who she is and what she is doing with her life."

238.title: "Le Fils de Cheval Fou Retrouve sa Mère"
238.author: Le Rallic
238.appears_in: p. 24-25 in Le Journal de Nano et Nanette, no. 196 (Nov. 15, 1960).
notes: "Résumé: Plusieurs mois se sont écoulés depuis l'anéantissement du 7e de cavalerie du général Custer par les Indiens de Sitting-Bull. La guerre de Sécession étant terminée, la cavalerie américaine se renforce et refoule les Indiens. Ceux-ci se trouvent obligés de se réfugier dans la grande forêt canadienne où leurs armes leur sont enlevées."
